body: After @nicolasnoble and I discussed it, I removed the cpp/codegen/golden_file_test because 1) problematic to get it running with bazel and 2) it's useless: it's only testing that the grpc proto compiler hasn't changed. When it did, whoever would just go and update the golden file. No actual testing of codegen is happening.

Please don't remove it.

It forces the generated code to be included in the code review, which
forces that code to also be reviewed: having it there catches real problems.

On Fri, Feb 17, 2017 at 5:09 PM David G. Quintas <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> After @nicolasnoble <https://github.com/nicolasnoble> and I discussed it,
> I removed the cpp/codegen/golden_file_test because 1) problematic to get it
> running with bazel and 2) it's useless: it's only testing that the grpc
> proto compiler hasn't changed. When it did, whoever would just go and
> update the golden file. No actual testing of codegen is happening.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you commented.
>
>
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/9773#issuecomment-280807997>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AJpuddxY6HfWCRXMdRW0rjGk4l0mE6Gxks5rdkTIgaJpZM4MEv8U>
> .
>

I agree with keeping it. In fact, we should extend it to all languages, not
just cpp. As much as I hated having to deal with it when I was working on
codegen, it does serve a real purpose with regard to compatibility and
other issues.
